title: 111_s2901
content:
The "Acquisition Workforce Improvement Act of 2009" establishes the Government-Wide Acquisition Management Fellows Program under the Office of Federal Procurement Policy Act. The Acquisition Workforce Improvement Act of 2009 establishes a government-wide acquisition management fellows program to invest in the long-term improvement of the Federal acquisition workforce. The program aims to develop new acquisition leaders with government-wide perspective, recruit individuals with outstanding academic merit and leadership skills, and offer advancement opportunities and competitive compensation upon completion. The government-wide acquisition management fellows program aims to recruit individuals with outstanding academic merit, ethical values, business acumen, and leadership skills to meet Federal Government acquisition needs. The program offers advancement opportunities, competitive compensation, and leadership roles at executive agencies. The program structure includes contracts with qualified universities for training, consisting of one year of full-time on-campus training followed by two years of on-the-job and part-time training towards a Masters or equivalent graduate degree. The government-wide acquisition management fellows program requires training at qualified universities for one year followed by two years of on-the-job training towards a Masters degree. The curriculum includes rotational assignments at executive agencies covering various acquisition topics. The government-wide acquisition management fellows program includes training in acquisition planning, cost estimation, contract administration, transparency, and integrity in the public contracting process. Additional courses may be required by participating universities. Priority for employment is given to program graduates. The government-wide acquisition management fellows program prioritizes hiring graduates for executive agency positions in the acquisition field at GS-12, 13, or 14 levels based on performance and qualifications. The government-wide acquisition management fellows program prioritizes hiring graduates for executive agency positions at GS-12, 13, or 14 levels, with a limit of 200 participants per year and a gradual increase in participants over time. The program must adhere to merit system principles and not conflict with the rights of preference eligible individuals. The government-wide acquisition management fellows program limits the total number of participants to 200 per year, with a minimum of 50 in the first year, 100 in the second year, and 150 thereafter. The Administrator is responsible for managing the program, entering into agreements with qualified universities, and overseeing participant placement upon graduation. Universities can select and remove participants following established academic processes. The government-wide acquisition management fellows program is overseen by the Administrator, who manages the program, places individuals upon graduation, and reviews career development to ensure objectives are met. Participants commit to federal employment in acquisition after completing the program. The Acquisition Fellows Program requires participants to commit to federal employment in acquisition for a specified term after completion. Candidates who do not fulfill the service requirements must reimburse the government for funds received. The Acquisition Fellows Program requires participants to commit to federal employment in acquisition for a specified term. If candidates do not meet the service requirements, they must reimburse the government for funds received. The OFPP Acquisition Fellows Development Fund is established to cover program expenses such as tuition, books, and materials. The OFPP Acquisition Fellows Development Fund covers program expenses including tuition, books, materials, room and board, travel, stipends, planning, administration, and other necessary expenses. The Fund is funded through deposits. The Fund is funded through deposits. The Government-wide acquisition management fellows program under section 45 of the Office of Federal Procurement Policy Act requires the Administrator to submit an initial report within 120 days of enactment and annual reports thereafter to the appropriate congressional committees. The reports should include a description of the program, activities, and budget needed. The Administrator must submit an annual report to congressional committees on the Government-wide acquisition management fellows program, detailing program activities, effectiveness, and any recommendations for legislative or administrative action. The Administrator must submit an annual report to appropriate congressional committees on the Government-wide acquisition management fellows program, assessing program effectiveness and providing recommendations for legislative or administrative action. The appropriate congressional committees include the Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs, the Committee on Appropriations of the Senate, the Committee on Oversight and Government Reform, and the Committee on Appropriations of the House of Representatives. Authorization of Appropriations for the OFPP Acquisition Fellows Development Fund:
- Senate Committees: Homeland Security, Governmental Affairs, Appropriations
- House Committees: Oversight, Government Reform, Appropriations
- Amounts authorized:
  - 2011: $16,000,000
  - 2012: $32,000,000
  - 2013: $48,000,000
